This game is so very touching. It's not realistic or logical (but it's not meant to be either).  It plays like a dream. Imagine how dreams can be rather senseless and illogical, but have that special, mystical feeling to them?   Well, that is how this game feels like.  This is not to say that the story doesn't make sense, because it does (for the most part).  So the story takes off with a patient (i.e. Johnny) at old age - on his deathbed - and wanting to fulfil his desire of going to the moon.  But how on earth is a man of such age to achieve such a thing?  Well, that's where a brilliant duo of doctors (aka Dr. Neil Watts & Eva Rosalene) come in.  They specialize in the art of memory-alteration, through use of a sophisticated machine, which is then connected to a patient's head - via a helmet - so as to grant them access to their patients' memory and alter their memories (as needed).  The game is played in a chronological, linear fashion (meaning, there's a certain routine to follow), which involves hopping from memory to memory, by interacting with mementos (i.e. items of sentimental value to the patient) which serve as a 'bridge' between one memory and the next & triggers the time-travelling process, within the patient's mind.  It's interesting to note however, that time-travel occurs in a backwards fashion (meaning, as you play you get to see the patient at old age first, and then hop back in time to a younger version - again & again - till a certain age is reached).  This is done for the purpose of creating a point of 'ignition' (in regard to Johnny's end-life desire of 'going to the moon'), meaning; the two doctors look for an ideal timeframe within Johnny's past to alter his memories, so as to encourage the fulfilment of his dream.  Mementos (encountered within the patient's mind) have to be 'activated' in order for them to serve as a 'link' to a specific memory.   This is achieved by touching them & going thru a process of solving a mini-puzzle.  The puzzle is of the 'tile'-type (where tiles are flipped in a methodical way so as to have them form an image - this is always an image of whichever memento is being worked on at that moment).  Also; these mementos are wrapped inside a protective bubble and have to be 'released' thru a certain mechanism, which is achieved thru the collection of so-called 'orbs' scattered across any area (i.e. school, home, yard, etc., ... ) that is up for exploration within the patient's mind.  Whether or not Johnny's dream is eventually achieved is left for the player to find out at the end of the game (no awful cliffhanger there, phew!).  The way the story ends, does make way for yet another episode (and hopefully this will be the case!).  There was such clever use of sound, music and words that created a beautiful experience and atmosphere maintained throughout the whole game.  Admittedly... it had me crying. The music, the story... the characters. Ahh... I love when a game has that effect on me - that's why I ultimately play - to have a good time. And I sure did!  NB I played this game with a Steam buddy and that impacted my experience positively (it's one of those games that serves as a great way to bond and share the many 'feels' evoked by the story).  UPDATE - NOMINATION:  This game should be nominated because:  - the plot in itself is very endearing (i.e. clever use of sound, music, scenarios) - the plot unfolds in a very original manner - it touches upon real-life issues with a fun sci-fi twist - gets you thinking about life, stimulates the mind & pulls quite a bit of heartstrings!
I am a 20 years old male that cried 3 times playing this Edit: still touching

This is definitely one of the best games in terms of story and music. Both are beautifully written and exceedingly emotional. I had some monumental expectations for 'To the Moon'. Seeing all of the reviewers claiming they cried, had me hope for a story that would keep me enthralled and emotionally invested the entire time.  While the story is emotional, dealing with a husband's struggles in living with a wife with a mental condition, there was one thing with the writing that kept bothering me...the doctors.  They pulled me out of the story almost every time they interacted. From snarky banter, to pop culture references, to pointless 'mini-games' involving    zombies??!   . I think they weren't written with the same serious tone as the rest of the story.  There is a major twist towards the end that I suppose is there to pull your heart strings, but there was no real build up to it and was in a completely different direction then where I thought the story was going.    I thought Anya was going to be a lost child, which would have suited the build up more and been a great cataclyst for River's change in condition.     I must say that you should complete this in one playthrough to get the impact of the story. I can see someone missing the emotion if they left the game and came back later to finish it.  I recommend people play this as it is a decent story. For a little more then the cost of a movie ticket and time to devote to it (it's 4 hrs long), it's something to experience, but I wish the writers had made the script hold up as maturely as the material.

Get this game o-o Do not expect fast paced combat, or any combat lol. but it has THE BEST story i have ever seen in a game D: better than most movies i see in theaters. There is a sequel on its way too, and I cant wait for it! I was on the edge going back and forth between buying this game or not... but i say go for it~ Everyone should get a chance to play this game. You won't regret it ^-^

After almost two years, I finally got around to playing 'To the Moon'. It's billed as an adventure game, but is really just a wonderful story told through JRPG mechanics. Great pixel art, good scripting and a wonderful soundtrack all make the experience enjoyable and very touching. It's a bit of a slow burn, at first, but once you get past the story setup, you'll be hard pressed to stop playing until the end.  'To the Moon' will tug at your heart in surprising ways. What are we and what is life, but the sum total of our memories and experience? And, at the end of your life, if you could change something from that experience, would you? And at what cost?  It's really thought-provoking stuff, and is told in a way that will make you smile, make you reflect on your life...and break your heart. Start to finish is only about three hours and, at the end, you'll get that same bittersweet feeling as when you finish a wonderful novel.
Great Story. ***** Pick this up when it's on sale for around $2 - $3.00.

This is an extremely underrated indie game. The characters are great, the humour is funny and light-hearted, and it is also extremely emotional and sad. Best story/plot for an indie game ever. Only bad thing is the controls. I don't know why, or if it was just me, but I found the controls are horrible. This is a great game for anyone who is looking for a good indie game with an amazing story.

Playing through this game I, as many of you would say, thought I was going to only play it for about a few minutes, to put it down, never to be played again.   Boy, was I wrong... This game was so undoubtedly touching that it nearly made me tear up about the characters. If you have the money to put toward this game, I'd suggest doing it. My 3.6 hours of gametime? Never moved. I was so drawn in to this game, that I never got up to do anything else. I was driven to finish this game. No saves, no loading, no restarting the application. Just sat here, and played the game.   10/10.

This is not really a game, more like an interactive comic book or cartoon, where your choices won't change anything. I have mixed feelings about this game; I love the story and the music, I don't even mind the old-school graphics, but I really hate that they tried to make this a 'game' at all. Really the 'interactive' parts were just annoying collect-the-crap adventures that jarred the flow of the story and temporarily ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off at the horrible controls.  In end though, the music and the thoughtful story made it definitely worth 'playing'. I'd just rather this were a comic.
A beautiful game. I Can't stop thinking about it.

This isn't a game, but it is a touching story told in reverse which still makes for a worthwhile experience. As the player you control the speed at which the story unravels but not much else and at times it all gets a bit repetive. Thankfully the 'experience' is short otherwise it could have ended up becoming tedious.  Perhaps acknowledging that people will be expecting some sort of gameplay there's a single repeating image puzzle element, but it's so easy and without any risk that it doesn't qualify. It's arguable that the developer should have had the courage to stick with their vision and omit the puzzles, they add nothing to the story and feel out of place.  So, this is a story, I should be reviewing that then. Well I don't want to give anything away about the ending, or should I say beginning since it's told in reverse? It's a slight love story, one of small coincidence, endurance through hardship and personal tragedy. It's not life changing or all that original, but if you have a shred of empathy and compassion then you will probably enjoy it. It's unclear whether the player has any control over the outcome, but I saw no point at which this was likely so there is no replay value.

Well, it's not a game exactly, and the parts of it that are game-like such as the sliding puzzles could be edited out entirely with no loss. But what a great experience. The story, the characters, the music, the humor, the 16-bit art style, and above all the pathos blend together to make a gem of a game. Which is not exactly a game, but who cares about that anyway?

Such a fantastic and emotional game... it's a casual game that focuses on the story rather than gameplay. Can get a bit repetitive in the middle but the ending is worth it. Keep in mind that It is a relatively short game, I took my time exploring everything and it only took less than 4 hours to finish.  Initially I only wanted the badges (they look really nice, go look them up on steam exchange :P) but as I went through the discussions I saw all the praise and so I got the game. I'm glad I got to play through this and I wouldn't be surprised to run through it again in the near future. :)

In just under 28 years of gaming experience I can without any hesitation say that this game... This random blip of completely unknown origin is by far the most emotionally driven game I've ever played in my entire life. Captivating, devastating, heart warming and soul shattering... This game tugs on the strings that is the human condition. The wonder that is each and everyone of us, and just how fragile we all really are. Fleeting, circumstantial, This game took it all on and I will confess to being emotionally overwhelmed... But in the best of ways. The story will take a hold of you and won't let go even long after you've completed the game. It's inconceivable to think that the majority of people will overlook this game.  Simply amazing, utterly groundbreaking. Ratings usually are a sum of their copy and paste criteria. Gameplay, visuals, etc etc... I'll be straight with you. The gameplay is little more than clicking on the screen to move your character. The visuals resemble something you'd see on early SNES. This isn't an adhd fix. This isn't an innovation in the mechanics of gaming. This is an interactive story that is relevant to every person on the planet right now. I believe strongly that you have to be in the right state of mind to jump into this game.. Even if just to buy it and keep it in your library of games. Leave yourself a reminder. Ever few days or so.. Until you feel like jumping into it. Stick with it and you'll be appalled at how studios with millions of dollars make it seem like gaming as a whole deserves to be phased out... While some random unheard of indie developer crafts a story and works 20 year old visuals to portray emotions that belittle everything the modern industry shovels out.   Do yourself a favor. Don't read reviews and don't look at the genre and scoff. Play the game. Experience what I'm trying to explain to you. You won't regret it.

In a nutshell, 'To the Moon' is the story of two doctors looking to fulfill the wish of a dying man named Johnny. His wish is to go, you guessed it, to the moon. The problem with that is he doesn't know why and it's up to the two doctors to find out and they do this by going into his memories. I won't spoil any of the plot for you but the journey is one well worth taking. I wouldn't exactly call 'To the Moon' a game per se. You basically look around the level for fragments of a memory which trigger a memento that helps you reach the next memory. After you trigger the memento, you have to do some light puzzle solving. Sometimes, you will have to do other things but this is the definiton of a casual game. There's no time limits, no right or wrong way to do things and you WILL eventually fulfill Johnny's wish to get to the moon. That's why I'd call this more of a visual novel than a game. The story is really what sucks you in. It's almost a nuisance to go through the gameplay because you just want to find out what happens. And I will say, this game about 80% in throws you a massive curveball I didn't see coming. Like System Shock 2 - SHODAN type curveball. Overall I'd recommend 'To the Moon' for it's wonderful story of love and loss and the superb soundtrack. Yes, you can loosely call this a 'game' but it's definitely worth a playthrough if you enjoy good stories. 7.5/10 from me.
You guys should be buying it.. Not only for the sake of your enjoyment, but also for supporting inteligent ideas on games.

In a word, this is devastating. It's not so much a game as it is a story you interact with, but there's just enough of that interaction to move you forward. Forward through something that I'd say is unique - at least, it's not often seen in this medium. I find it very difficult to relate why it's such a great piece of fiction, without potentially ruining your own experience with it.  Suffice it to say that I genuinely recommend playing To the Moon.
This game is awesome, I cried like a little ♥♥♥♥♥.
The first and probably only game that will make me cry. It was such a good story, and the soundtrack is so peaceful and soothing too, I just want to listen to it again and again. 10/10.

i must say this it the best game i have ever tried. i see myself cold as ♥♥♥♥ but this game broke me, this is so emotinal that at the end your chest hurts. this is an experience that no one should miss. if you don´t have it. BUY IT 10/10
once of the best i ever played :3

'To The Moon' is a lovely game that you will not be able to forget for a long, long time to come. The heart-warming story and excellent plot, are complete with the right dose of nostalgia in the visuals as well as the music.  As an artist, I'm often looking for references that excite, emote, and inspire - this just hits the spot.  Thank you for this beautiful piece of art, Ken and team!
Grapics - 8/10 Pixel Art - 9/10 System - 9/10 Character - 10/10 Funny dialogues - 10/10 Story - 15/10 Music - 16/10  Overall - 11/10 A MUST-PLAY work. BUY IT WITH OST NOW.
Bravo just Bravo! Never knew crying would feel so good. 10/10 would play and cry again.

Highly Recommended.  This is the best game of this genre I have ever played. Not because there's so much action or so many choices but because the story is just so beautiful. I found myself relating to some of the characters very well and understanding why they did what they did throughout the story. It's an extremely emotional game, if you pay attention to the story (Which is a must, if you wish to enjoy the game). While it is a rather sad story, the game doesn't leave you alone and sad as the two characters that discover the story are very close and understand each other. They often bicker and it ends up as a perfect mix between story, emotion and humor. I found it extremely enjoyable.  The soundtrack is also brilliant! It gets a little repetitive if you spend to much time in one area but other than that, the detail in the audio of the game (Including sounds) is of a high quality.  My recommendation: If you haven't got this game yet, make sure to add it to your 'To-Play' list. It really is a story worth hearing.

Manly tears were shed.... beautiful game. Touchig story, a game that teaches how life is short and how love can be the spark for any dream you have. Fun gameplay and storyline is fantastic. One off the few games that i persoally loved to play, a gem that can't be outlooked.

I would say it's not just a game that you play to kill time, you play 'to the moon' to learn something that you, yourself, might not even be able to put it into words.  There will be a mix of feelings and emotions that will run through your little beating organ which occasionally will make it skip or crack, but the other time it will warm you up from the inside.
Not much of a game, one hell of a story. Honestly, I'd just buy it for the soundtrack, even. That ♥♥♥♥ is 10/10

Incredible storytelling and pacing. This game reaffirms that games do not have to be about cutting-edge graphics in order to stir emotion in players.

One my my favourite games of all time. Honestly, I didn't expect much from this indie title. But, I ended up beating it and loved every second of the experience. To the Moon is an incredible game. The story is about two scientists who have the technology to access peoples memories, and use this technology to grant people their final wish on their death bed. It's an interesting premise, and it works so well. The patient that is dying is Johnny Wyles. His last request is strange...to go to the moon. The scientists need to go into his earliest memories and plant an idea - or thought - of going to the moon. This is where the story starts to unravel. You learn about Johnny's past memories, like his wife River and her condition, and his friends in school. The story is just amazing, and is the first game that made me cry this much. The story is so good because of the emotional impact on the player. This is a game I will remember for years to come. Not to mention the whole game is accompanied by a beautiful soundtrack! Not everything is perfect though, like the controls being a bit unresponsive at times, but with everything else in the game that is good, it's easy to overlook these minor gripes. The game also has a great 16bit art style. I never knew that a 16bit game would make me bawl my eyes out, and even though the dialogue is all text, there is still so much emotion. There are some sections of comedic relief that are pretty funny, and some very tense and gripping moments as well. Anyways, To the Moon is one of the best games I have played in the past few years even if it's not really a game. (Since it's really all about the story). 10/10
Story rich game with amazing soundtrack. Note: Don't forget the tissues.
I'm not crying theres something in my eye!
All the feels, in all the right places.
Already played through the game but bought it again on Steam to support the devs. This game is so good. It's so insanely good. It is SO GOOD.

To the Moon is a beautiful short story. I must say, however, that after hearing so many good things about the game, I found it rather disappointing... but that isn't the game's fault, so I still recommend it. Just don't expect to cry your eyes out and be traumatized forever, as some people on the internet would have you think. It's a nice and clever story, there's not much to do as long as gameplay goes, but as it usually happens in this kind of games, this should be considered more as an alternative way to tell a story than a proper game. An interactive story, you could say. The writing is funny, the OST is extremely well done and catchy, and since I also like olives and platypuses, I definitely recommend To the Moon.   If playing a localised version (thank you devs for having the game translated!) be aware that you'll have to change the language to English and play again through the last scene in order to get the achievement. Oh, and don't forget to play the two free DLC (a.k.a mini-sodes). They're a nice free addition, though I really hate cliffhangers and every single ending has one. And the mini-sodes should have been included somehow directly in the menu of the main game. The way they are currently implemented is quite sloppy and I believe this wouldn't be that hard to fix. Despite all this, To the Moon is a nice story worthy of a playthrough... a great story, yes, but still not quite what I would call a  game . As long as you are okay with this, I'm sure you'll enjoy it :)
this game is like the legend of zelda majora's mask except in reverse

To the Moon is one of the most refreshing gaming experiences I've had to date. While the gameplay is basically nonexistent, the story is really what people will stick around for. I would HIGHLY recommend this to gamers who are interested in story over gameplay or just an emotional journey. The story is really where this game strikes gold. It's beautifully and uniquely told and all wraps up to an absolutely astonishing final act that can come off as cliche is truly heartwarming. The score is also wonderfully crafted and is wonderfully placed into the story.  If you're looking for an enriching, gripping story about love and loss, then this game will be for you. If you're looking for an RPG or anything resembling the common constructs of a game, this won't be for you. Enjoy the experience that was laid out here and you'll understand why I so highly recommend this game.
An extremely touching story coupled with great characters and witty dialogue!!
A beautiful piece of creative storytelling, and the only game to ever make me cry.

Someone once said (I think) that the meaning of tragedy in narrative is to let us channel our sadness, sorrow, into something far greater: an escape or an elevation. To consume a tragedy and shed tears because of it is to see our own shortcomings and faults, to understand the human condition and, while feeling sorrow for it, to overcome the mere sadness of unpleasant and unwanted things. The goal is to understand that while we are 'only' human, each and every life story in the context of humanity is an epic in itself. Sounds grandiose, doesn't it?  Well, I think that if we agree with what I said before, To the Moon is one of the great tragedies of modern gaming. It is a story monumental by itself: it is mostly the story of a single man and his love and memories, but in its execution it brings us to the shore of nostalgia, fondness, appreciation and - most of all - empathy for our fellow man. This is one of the greatest stories I have experienced. I recommend it for everyone.

Very emotionally driven, the writing was very well done, and although the game was fairly short I felt that it did not need a long play through to satisfy me. I highly recommend this game if you enjoy deep stories and look to feel in touch with the characters you play.

How can you not cry/feel bad after playing this game? This game made me think about life. Don't let this stop you from playing the game though. To The Moon is more than a game. It's an experience. Watching playthroughs isn't the same as playing the game. The gameplay isn't really long at all, it took me about 6 hours to complete it on my first play around. (Literally, like I watched Cryaotic play this game, and cried. I bought the game myself... AND STILL CRIED) I still love it. The story will never get old to me. It's unique, unheard of, emotional, everything a great game has. Most people think this game is boring because all you do is solve puzzles and walk around. No. Just no. Those people aren't actually enveloped in the feels and the emotion of the game.   To The Moon has one of the BEST storylines in a game that I have ever played. To The Moon is for everyone. Literally. It also has those funny moments that Watts brings in. Now that there's Steam Cards, replay is going to be helpful. Get ready to get hit in the feels once again.  This is, without a doubt, beauty and perfection in their final forms. Simply stunning. The original soundtrack is also perfect and makes you feel even more. We're all in this together people... The feels on the bus go round and round...  Kan Gao has made a MASTERPIECE. And I can't wait for Episode 2 to be finished. Keep a look out for A Bird Story. It's a prequel to the second patient in the series. Check Freebird Games website often for chances to get limited edition items from To The Moon and get updates about the new upcoming game A Bird Story.  10/10

This is a great game for telling a very emotional story. The gameplay mechanics were very relaxed, so there wasn't much pressure to progress at an unnatural pace. *sigh* Completed 2 indie games in a row in one sitting? GG, no life. --------------------------------------------------------------------- WARNING:Possible implied spoilers (will try my best not to give out major ones)  !$@!$#$%#$ Where do I start? I felt like going on an indie game spree today, so I started off with the swapper then I end up here. 'To the Moon' is most emotionally compelling game I've ever played, and that says a lot for 3 hours (other time spent afk), nothing compares to what this game gave in such a small amount of time. Don't let the $10 price tag fool you, if you can read I can assure you you'll get your money's worth 10 folds.   Although I've nitpicked 'The Swapper' for it's lack of a challenge, 'To the Moon' sets the bar so high I won't even dock points for it's simplicity(really, unless you can't read, there's no reason at all not to buy this game). For 'emotionally compelling', I can defintely say this game leads closely towards the sad side. Kan Gao beautifully inserts questions into your mind while consistently lets you find out the answer for yourself, along this sea of grief, he seamlessly inserts halarious comic reliefs, such as the joke Final Fantasy styled battle at the beggining of the game (there really is no legit fighting).   Although I'd like to type more, It would end up with me giving major spoilers. As a note towards the ending, it's a little controversial and I'd agree that it could of been a little different in the audience's favor, in the end there's no denying that it's still extremely well done (along with the mind ♥♥♥♥ if you pay attention during the bridge scene and at the end of the credits). Coincidentially, I happen to be playing this game a week after it's successor, 'A Bird Story' was released a week ago, it happens to be more story oriented and I will be looking foward to getting it with high expectations (not of that which compares to To the Moon however, we've seen this happen before and it does not end well with fans.)  Overall, one of my first legit reviews (You need to upvote my other ones, like now) 10/10. (11/10 if the movement was perfected --- that's really the only con for me)  EDIT: Can't believe I left off the part that contributed the most to the story--- THE MUSIC, transitioned well throughout the whole game
a must play for romantic souls and musical souls
It's a nice story, but not really a game. Some very simple puzzles is all gameplay here so buy (and ''play'') it for it's story.
Better buy this for 8 euros and finish this beatufiull game in 4 hours than buy COD for 50 euros and finish it for 5 hours  LOVE THIS GAME!

Awesome story! Definitely one of the best games I've played this year!
cried for 3 days and got addicted to origami  10/10
Best story told in a video game, along with a heartbreaking piano music. Made me cry at the last 30 minutes.. Wholeheartedly recommended.  For it's price is a steal...
A really good story told in a Game Maker game...as surprising as it is, definetly worth a purchase, music is pretty good too.

I don't know how to explain how I feel about this game.  Nor do the people I've made to play it.   It's not happiness or sadness... It's love I guess. A love that I wished existed in life as well.  10/10 would recommend.
The most beautiful game ;3 <3

Even if this game wins the “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” award, you're being lied to. You'll most likely cry like a little ♥♥♥♥♥ during this game.  3-4 hours for a playthrough and obviously not really much replay-value. Combined with the lack of options menu and actual gameplay-elements this might seem bad. But To The Moon tells a story and does it so incredibly well. Which is amazing since storytelling is something only very few games actually do a good job on (the only other example I can think of is Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons). That great story and the amazing soundtrack which always sets the mood perfectly makes for a real gem of a small indie game.

If you like a good story, this is the game for you. Think Inception meets Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. As a harderened rarely emotional person, even I started to feel a little overwhelmed at the end.  There isn't much in the way of puzzle / game play here, it's more of an interactive story. Move around, click on objects to fill your quota before you can move on to the next stage. With effective pixel art and a beautiful sound track, it's a feast for all senses.   A short but sweet game for evening.  The only annoyances I had, were some trouble with resolutions and the hotspots for items were sometimes small and unreliable - which meant revisiting rooms because you missed something that didn't show up in your mouse scans. Steam overlay refused to work as well, and for my particular setup, alt-tabbing out caused it to misbehave. None of these issues are severe enough for me not to recommend it though.

To The Moon is an emotionally heartwrenching puzzle game which, upon first glance, disguises itself as an RPG. It's a fantastic and creative use of the RPG Maker engine, and the story is masterfully crafted, skyrocketing the player backwards in time through the memory of a dying old man. The way each plot point is approached and answered through an exploration of the past is fascinating, and I would definitely reccomend To The Moon to any fans of heavily narrative games.

As a artist I do see some miner flaws in the hand drawn images as its missing some basic fundamentals. Such as composition, detail separation, anatomy, perceptive, line weight, and so on. but it almost docent matter, As it still works fine for telling the story at hand. and the average viewer probably wont notice the minute details. One of my favorite stories I've ever read/played. The plot is well developed and thoroughly enjoyable. This game is a steal at its current sale price!  Art is simplistic but amazing in its own style. The characters have nice designs and I love the level design. It's such a beautiful game -- nothing I'd expect out of a game I'd never heard of before its sale.  As for controls, the movement with clicking can be a bit annoying, but it's really no big deal. The puzzles are easier than I thought they'd be. I don't think going for the 'ideal' amount of moves on all the puzzles does anything significant, so no need to be stubborn like I was and keep trying to find the ideal move order.   The soundtrack for this game is amazing. After launching the game for the first time, I was awed by the main menu track and knew it'd be well worth my time even if it were just for the music. Throughout the game, the soundtrack worked well to produce an appropriate atmosphere, as the soundtracks were very nice and fitting.  TLDR: I can't recommend this game enough. The story is fascinating and the soundtrack is worth the price of the entire game.
I was immediately drawn in and captivated by the story. The gameplay itselft is very basic but that didn't detract my enjoyment from the experience.

1. Stop whatever you are doing now and will be doing for the next 5 hours. Make sure you are ALONE. 2. Buy this game, start playing it, and thank me later.  To the moon is a simply brilliant, an example of masterpiece storytelling within an RPG. I had high expectations from this game after going through the reviews, and despite this, I was blown away. I had no choice but to call an all nighter to finish it in one sitting.  Playing this game feels much like watching a very well directed movie, except that you can move around and interact with things within this movie, making the experience more surreal. Considering the concept of the game, I was hoping to find few flaws, but there wasn't anything noticable or blatantly flawed. Moreover, the subtleties incorporated within the game are laudable. The various parts of the game were interwoven brilliantly.  The music, and the attention given to their placements, as well as the sound effects, was amazing. The music in To The Moon is among the best OSTs I have encountered, not because there were awesome, but because they played so well with the entire game and were placed so well to suit the moments.

Where do I begin.  I can't begin to express what I'm feeling right now, and I would never want too. I'd want you to experience yourself. I used to scroll past this game every time I ever looked through the recommended listings in the Steam Store as I deemed it as something I wouldn't like.  I was dead wrong.  Without ruining anything about the game, if you love RPG games, not nessecarily horror games, but any RPG games, I would highly recommend this one. Play with an open mind, and an open heart. 'To the Moon' will rock your world.
10/10 I cri everytim T T

I've written two reviews in my years on Steam. This is one of them. This game is touching to your very core and the music is wonderful. I streamed it on Twitch with a few viewers and everyone was enthralled, constantly trying to figure out what was actually going on and what we weren't being told. And we were all wrong. And I'm glad we were wrong, because the ending was much better than anything I had thought of.  This story will stay with you.

To the Moon is best described as an interactive story. The gameplay itself was minor and very casual and that's great, because I found myself willing to 'read' more into the story and willing it to progress. The story itself was amazing, with a very cool premise, and I found myself thinking multiple times throughout that I would enjoy this as a movie. Truly one of my favourite games of all time. (Completed in 3hrs)

+Amazing soundtrack +Well written, realistic story +Decent characters, although some of them are over-comical in a forced manner +Easy to grasp controls +Moving game with a positive and powerful message, although it is sad at times  +/-This game is quite emotional if you like that thing.    -The story can be confusing at times because it works backwards    -little to no replay value due to single ending -very straightforward, one path storyline with no decisions -sometimes it feels like more of a movie or VN than an game -short  Overall a rewarding game that will make you think.

'To the Moon' is a fantastic RPG created by a lovely indie company known as Freebird Games. The game starts off with a light-hearted mood full of jokes and hilarious commentary. However, as you progress through the game, you will start to care more about the story than anything else. The story focuses on two doctors who work to bring a dying person's final wish to life. The doctors travel throughout the person's memories and alters them to allow for their final wish to be granted. Once the story begins to close, you will express your despair for its ending, then only desolation as life goes on.  8.5/10

You play two doctors who are exploring the memories of their patient to figure out why his dying wish is to go to the moon. Basic point and click with some very easy puzzle in-between sections. The game play, however, is not what is the selling point for To the Moon. The story line was amazing and emotional, and I loved it to bits. To the Moon costs $9.99 at full price. Some people may say, 'Wait for a sale.' Well... I have something to say about that...  To the Moon can be completed in under 2 hours, around 1 hour if you rush it. Why would you pay $10 for an hour long game with almost no replay value? I'll tell you why! It's because even though the game may be under 2 hours, the impact it will have on you will be lifelong. They could have charged full price ($59.99) for this game and it would still be more than worth it in my opinion.  This game is a fantastic example of emotionally moving narrative. 9/10 people will cry at the end of the game (myself included). Did telling this story using interactive medium enhance the narrative (like with Undertale)? No, not really (in fact I would love to see a movie adaptation of this game).  Now with its sequel Finding Paradise set for release next summer, everyone who has any interest in great narrative should pick up To the Moon as soon as possible.

Sweet and short (about 4 hours) - some nice audio and a visual style to remind you of the good old days of RPGS back on the SNES or N64. Very heavily centred around the narrative - it's almost more of an interactive novel than a 'game' by traditional definitions. Most areas require you to find 5 items to move you on to the next area, but honestly it's all just there to break the plot up and to give you a chance to look around the nice environments. Plus, the occasional video game in-joke stops the subject matter from ever being too depressing. Characterisation of the two leads is very entertaining, would happily play a sequel with the same central concept and characters.  P.S. For those who have already played (or, should you buy and complete it...) there is a special 20 to 30 miniute long holiday themed bonus section. You have to nagivate to the folder install location and manually go to the holiday special folder, but it amused me so I'd recommend checking it out if you like the main game.

These feels is so real  An elegant, beautiful story that spans but four hours. A touching, poignant reminder of what it means to live, what we mean to eachother, and how much any given life can mean or become. Brought a tear to my eye, I think I'll remember this one to days end.

This may be the most emotional game I have ever played. I had an idea of what to expect, after several youtube videos I watched put it up as a top indie game and one of the more emotional titles on the market. However, despite my high expectations, I had no clue it would blow me away quite like it did. The gameplay- simple yet satisfying. No action, yet completely entertaining. Heartwarming story, beautiful message, and a satisfying ending for a story about a man dying (no spoilers there, I swear). The artwork is amazing for a job done by such a small team, and the soundtrack is one of the best in existance. There is no need for a full orchestra in the soundtrack for it to hold up against the epic scores from legends like Hans Zimmer and John Williams. To The Moon is a simple, emotionally driven tale that is sure to bring a tear to anyone's eye. By far one of the best indie games I have ever had the privilege to experience. 10/10 would play (and cry) again
Just buy it... it's worth it...

To the Moon is clearly one of the best games I've played.  I must admit that it was hard for me to get past the 16bit graphics, but after half an hour I totally forgot about it. Don't let the graphics make you think twice before purchasing this game (as it happened to me). Everything is so good about it, that the graphics don't count.  The great story and the excellent original music make the atmosphere of this game one hard to forget.

To the Moon is more an interactive story than a game, but it is one of my all time favorite works of art, no matter what genre you put it in. The story is creative, humorous, and heart-touching—and worth playing through again every so often. The music is also incredible and brings a lot of life and feeling to the story.  The only things that might get in the way of the story are the simple graphics and the puzzles. In my opinion, however, the graphics don't take away from the story at all, but rather help keep the focus on the story. The puzzles do distract from the story some, but there are few enough of them and they're simple enough that they don't detract from the story much.  Overall, To the Moon is an incredible game. I will recommend it to anyone who likes a good, emotional story. Personally, I will always hold it close to my heart.
oooooooooohooooo buy it and all dlc pls

I've never played a game with such a well written story. The amazing story combined with the amazing music exceeded my expectations that I had because of the price and the looks of the game at first.   When I started the game I was still a bit sceptical. I heard that it had a great story and that I needed to brace myself for the feels that where about to come. But the game starts a bit slow. My advice: don't stop at the beginning, push trough and you'll find an amazing game with more feels you will ever be able to handle.  Its also worth to buy the soundtrack (I know youtube is out there with the soundtrack), the developers of this game can't get enough support and the music is so amazing that you just need to have it.  Pros: +Best story I've ever seen in a game +Music that fits amazingly well and adds to the story +Well made pixel art +Easy controls so you can focus on the story +Such a low price for such an amazing game +Great character development   Although you go back in time and learn about the past, not the future   +Great environmental use, every place you visit connects to the story  Cons (not really): -Can be rather short in the eyes of some people (the 2 mini chapters make up for that) -The start of the game is a bit slow, you really have to push through the start -There is no option in-game for sound (graphics are not really a problem ^^)  P.s Bring as much tissues as you can carry. You can't bring enough.

However, at only four hours, it wouldn't hurt to take a little detour down heartbreak road. Great music, charming graphics and the two playable characters are funny and likable. Recommend with tissues.

If it was just for the gaming part, this product would score rather low. The adventure-typical riddles are hardly present at all, the few mini games need few skill, and the handling by mouse needs some adjustment. Luckily the story makes more than up for such shortcomings. A tale of a fulfilled life, that lacks one last wish. A tragic tale of loss and burdens, that make life what it is. A lovers tale, shown in touching sensitivity. Lightened up through occasional snarky comments by the protagonists. These days, many games strive to build a movie-worth story, while not reaching even halfway decent results. This one gets close. Enjoy it as a piece of slightly interactive fiction. This game made me cry, and that doesn't happen very often. [Nominated for tear jerker award Nov 2016]

This game is a phenomenal piece of interactive fiction. There isn't really any difficulty, or much gameplay at all really, but if you want to sit back, relax, and click through a tremendous story, play this game.

Boy oh boy...  *Note: for all those that look and see that I only have 3.5 hours into the game, let me say that this is a short story game, not some massive JRPG that takes years to beat. 3 or 4 hours is PLENTY to finish the storyline*   I couldn't recommend this game enough. It was a huge success in storytelling, with story twists every and a large variety of emotions conveyed. There were no loose ends or unexplained mysteries that were not solved in the end (except for one deliberate cliffhanger after the credits). The world was immersive and made sense. Every character had a set backstory and had much to be learned about. On top of all this, the soundtrack is absolutely immersive, one of the best since...well...ever. Up until now the Halo franchise has held this spot.  Of course, I'm not just some fanboy ranting on all the positives. For one, the gameplay was a bit repetitive for about 3 quarters of the game (it livened some towards the end) but this was most likely to put more focus on the narrative. Still, would've been nice to see deeper interaction. The scenery was lovely, but apparently small tufts of grass or flowers are just as tall as a lighthouse because I could walk through neither, which got very frustrating seeing how the landscape was littered with flowers. Turned into a maze wherever I walked. And with all RPGs, the movement was a bit sticky, being based off of a grid-like moving system.   But for a game like this, I could almost call it a work of art. For those looking for a relatively quick sit-down and want a deep story experience, this is your game.   I rate 10/10 moons.

To the Moon is more of an interactive story book where the decisions you are prompted to make only add or lessen the amount of detail you are given overall. It does not change the outcome of the story, so you shouldn't be thinking too heavily about it. Most of the other selection bits throughout the story are more of the 'are you ready to move on to the next scene' sort of thing.  But I definitely loved the story and I loved the twists in the plot. For me, it just happened to be one of those reads that I wanted to sit through from start to finish. I wouldn't be satisfied until I got to the very end. I laughed, I cried, and I would definitely recommend this for others who want to enjoy a good story.

I'm one of those people who writes short stupid reviews for likes because we are like ♥♥♥♥♥s. This game however, does not deserve something like that. This game plays with your emotions, if you care.. you will love this game. This game offers a beautiful soundtrack, that alone can make you cry, and we've only covered the surface. The story here is the best i've ever experienced. This is more of an interactive adventure more than a game, think of this as a 5 hour movie. Your objective is to venture the mind of an old man and fulfill his wish to go to the moon by making him think so in his sleep. Seems simple? No, it's way more complex that. You will fall in love and bond with every single character, this game will teach you how important 'time' is. If you are looking to cry the hell out of manlihood, you can buy this for a mere 10 bucks. A game this stupendous is worth 20 bucks even when it is 4 hours long. This is one of those things that are capable of changing your life. This game teaches you that there is a place for every choice you make, no matter how small it is, you might be an astronaut rather than a teacher if you went to the coffee shop this tuesday instead of wednesday. You are either finishing this crying, or finishing this crying and a changed man. Truly an adventure no one should miss. 10/10 <3 Does this game offer good gameplay? No. Good controls? Heck no! Even when it has nothing a normal game has, the story and the sound itself is so good, It steals my perfect 10 score, that is saying something.
A very engaging and touching story not really a game you play more like one you watch with a few interactive elements, needless to say I had a great time playing...episode 2?

A deeply moving and well-written piece of video game art. This is one of those stories that, as soon as it's finished, you know that you will never forget. Surprisingly engrossing with an amazing soundtrack, I couldn't recommend this game more.

To the Moon is a masterpiece in terms of storytelling. It draws one into the beautiful world, and mind, of a dying man, Johnathan 'Johnny' Wyles. In time, no pun intended, it unravels his rich and mysterious life that has led up to the beginning of the game. Although the gameplay is lacking, as the puzzles are composed mainly of simplistic tile flipping mini-games, To the Moon makes up for it with its spectrum of emotions ranging from humor to sorrow, all of which are experienced at a wonderful pace.  Needless to say, I would definitely recommend this game as the story is satisfying, unforgettable, and tugs at one's heartstrings.   Two years later, still good!

This game is a true work of art. In a gaming world full of endless cliches and spectacle creep, this game dares to tell a simple story of an old man, wanting to fulfill one final wish. As you progress through the game, you learn more about this man and his life and his poignant tale of love and loss. The music is also pitch-perfect and matches the mood perfectly. This 4 hour emotional journey is small in length, but packs a powerful punch that has embedded itself deep into my memory where it will remain cherished and celebrated.

Sometimes all a narrative game needs is a good story and you can forgive the faults. However, To The Moon has everything going against it despite having a very unique and interesting story.  The dialogue is quite bad. At some times cringeworthy, and other times just missing the mark on a joke/reference. It feels as if the author knew the destination for their story, but didn't put enough effort into how the characters would get there.  The music does all the heavy lifting. Due to the terrible dialogue, the game relies on the amazing soundtrack to carry you through the story beats. This is the biggest strength of this game because the music completely nails every setpiece. I'm confident if they removed every line of dialogue from this game, used only emotes and sprite work, this would be a knockout.  The controls are frustrating. Since you are really just walking around in this game, easily moving your character around should be a top priority. However, your character advances too many steps in a button press, leaving you to run into many walls because you overshot.  A very unique story dragged down from the sum of its faults.

5.5 hours. I'm finished. For me the ending was not a sad ending at all. On the contrary, it was a happy ending because it was FINALLY OVER. I have never put myself through so much tedium ever in my whole life and I have all the glowing reviews to thank. This is not a game. You don't level a character, you don't affect the out come, you are simply given mindless disjointed repetitive tasks to accomplish before you are permitted to move on with the story. Thats it. Imagine if you were forced to get 5 pennies into a Jack Daniels jar from accross the room in order to turn the next page of your favorite novel. Do you enjoy poorly rendered versions of Whack-a-mole? You'll LOVE this game. I don't care how great how sad or how touching the story was... because by the time I was finished I was so bored and frustrated (spoiler alert) that I was hoping the shuttle would explode and kill everyone... including the idiots on the bridge.
The story is beautiful but short, really short. And the puzzle is too easy, actually, there is no puzzle at all. It's just an adventure. I love the story so much, I don't regret buying thing.

Brilliant game. Great story, beautiful soundtrack. This is really more of an interactive novel in some respects. The click and find with a puzzle between each section works very well. It's sentimental, but so good.  I'm going to say something controversial. I'm really tired of blocky pixel art and the retro style. There's nothing wrong with retro styling and pixel art, but too many view them with rose tinted glasses and there is an excess of it in the indie/budget land. Cell shaded 2-D graphics can work really well, look at Braid, Bastion, Spelunky as examples. Cutesy is fine too, but a fair few games out there seem to end up with characters so blocky that it's hard to care. This game does a little more with the graphics and the story is interesting. A special mention has to go to the dialogue between characters that works incredibly well (especially Dr. Watts amusing lines and moments - SF2 ;) ). Conversations contain remarks that are much more realistic than the predictable dross that you hear in many films.  I like my FPS, action RPG with their fancy graphics, and maybe I am unaware of what is out there, I never got into the JRPG and other such games in their heyday (8/16-bit days) but it is great to see gaming go in these directions. I certainly hope to see more games with an emotional focus. Maybe first person drama rather than shooter.

An absolutely incredible game, beautiful and heartbreaking and bittersweet. The gameplay was styled like a typical rpg, but except for a (fake) fight near the beginning that served as a nod to the form, the actual 'gameplay' was pretty minimal and consisted of going from point to point piecing together the story of a dying man's memories. I think it was so bittersweet because the memories were of a very normal life, with all its attendant regrets and triumphs. It felt real and immediately relatable. While probably not for everyone (considering that there was very little in the way of 'action'), it was one of the most emotionally-affecting games I've ever played and I would strongly recommend it.

Let's get this out of the way, yes, To The Moon is probably the best Free to Play, physics infused, subscription based MMO style dating sim currently on the market. The lack of spoken dialougue made me harken back to the days of reading books where I read what was being spoken but not actually hearing it (except for audiobooks of course). Now what makes this dating sim so unique, well it just does everything so well, but adds a few things in to freshen it up. Ken Gao is probably the best 40 year old Asian video game writer there is, filling the characters with such classic lines like:  'Ken Gao' '...the...' 'Follow through' 'Name of the Wind' 'Walk' 'Pearl Harbor' 'Dating Sim' 'Frankie Muniz' etc.  The writing is so spectacular, I needed olive oil to calm myself down. Now my Indonesian roomate by the name of Kareem Abdul Jabaar was watching me play this emotionally charged First Person Shooter, when he turned to me and said, 'Are you an angel?'  Confused I turned to him and told him that I was indeed, and we hugged it out for 47 hours. We deficated and urinated together, but it was for the sake of pleasing Kareem, YOU GO GIRL!  The next pro in the never ending list, would be the graphics. Now Ken Gao knows that we haven't had a true story in video games since Tetris, so he intentionally made terrible graphics, in order to give the audience the same wonder when that first Tetris block fell down hard.  The next item, would be the lasting appeal, now it may say that I have eight minutes on this game, but I played in offline mode for a good 2,000 hours because of all of the sweet end game content, that made me both happy and warm. Due to Ken Gao's facsination with antiques and the like, he treated die hard fans, such as myself, to an 40 hour documentary on the breeding habits of chimpanzees living in captivity (with full naration by Steve Irwin himself!). It is incredibly rewatchable. Let's just say Blockbuster better watch out because Ken Gao is gonna suck you dry!  Let me be (Ken Gao) real with you for a second, the music, oh, the music, AHHHHH!!!! As you probably know by now, Elton John and his partner Niel Patrick Harris put in so much effort into this incredibly composed piece of virtual literature. My favorite song in this by far would have to be 'Lick my Love Pump' it is gosh darn good.  Now my favorite part about this story driven game, is the lack of gameplay. I turn it on, click start and I'm off to another world. The lack of interactivity allowed me to participate in other activities, such as:  Playing League of Legends Writing Steam reviews Buying CS GO keys Buying hats Dreaming about Ken Gao Listening to the soundtrack for the movie Freaky Friday starring Lindsay Lohan Listening to the soundtrack for the video game To The Moon Listening to an audio book Contracting an STD etc.  Let's just say leaving this game on and then doing something else while the game completed itself has allowed me to buy newer and cleaner oils for bathing, as well as find my soul mate in life. With this game your productivity will go, dare I sat, To The Moon.  Ken Gao.  Alright, alright reviewer, I get it this game is heavenly, but there has to be faults.  Yes, yes there are faults to To The Moon. Even a perfect game is not without cons so I will list them below:         etc.  So there you have it, Ken Gao has been impregnated, had morning sickness, craved foods, went into labor, and birthed yet another masterpiece that will be beloved by sensitive men and hipsters that happened to stumble upon an IGN review of it. So I can say without a doubt, go and purchase To The Moon, for only 16:9 Widescreen.   (P.S. Lock the frame rate at 1fps for the most cinematic of experiences).  10/10 Would soak Ken Gao in Thousand Island Dressing again.

It manages to capture the (S)NES era perfectly, with a lot of references to it. As it’s well balanced on jokes and serious matters alike, it makes it easy to consume.  One suggestion, just complete it at once in a 5 hour session, to avoid missing out on the details.   +Wonderful story +Touching and funny at the same time +Lots of references to pop culture and times long past  +Doesn’t fail to entertain despite the lack of actual gameplay +SNES graphics  -Not challenging -Could’ve used some variety in mini-games and puzzles -Sometimes wanders off a little too far from the main theme  8+/10

To The Moon isn't really a game. Don't get me wrong, I love it! The story is great! The problem with it is that you cannot fail. There is no failure state. You will always end up winning the game. So mostly, the thing that makes up the game is the story, and if you don't like it, you will not like the game. The gameplay consists of finding objects or exploring an area and connecting them all together to make a memento, which puts you in a sort of puzzle game, in which you line up parts of a picture to complete it. If the game itself was just what the small amount of gameplay is, it would be boring. There are also some other pockets of different gameplay, which are alright. I love how the graphics look, a 16 bit look with some bloom that makes it seem more like a memory. The story follows two people who work for a corporation that rewrites people's memory on their deathbed, and as they work on a man who wants to go to the moon, and he doesn't know why. Overall, I love this game, the story kind of reminded me of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, and it is great.

To the Moon is an original and very creative work that I find a little hard to refer to as a game, due to the relatively few critical interactions available and the complete linearity of the plot. However, unlike A Bird Story, which I thought would have been better as a non-interactive 'movie' using the game engine, To the Moon had enough interactivity to keep it interesting, even if the player was unable to make any choices that really changed the game experience in any way, I guess I think of it as an 'experience' similar to a very easy adventure game.  The story is alternately beautiful, funny, corny, and tongue-in-cheek. The setting is enjoyable, and the main plot device is very imaginative and well thought through. The writing itself is simple, but excellent, and in terms of grammar is much better than most AAA games available today.  The music is delightful, if a bit repetetive (a fact that does not go unnoticed by some of the game's characters). And even though by the end one knows exactly where the story is going, it is still heartwarming -- and also sad -- enough to bring a tear to the eye, while the occasional jokes and unexpectedly offbeat situations were funny enough to elicit a least a few genuine laughs from me, and quite a number of chuckles.  As with A Bird Story, but even more so here, the pixel graphics are brilliant. There's a wide range of settings throughout the story, each with a unique feel, but I did find myself becoming a bit sick of some of the repeated areas, even though they were required for the plot.  To the Moon even has some minigames to break up the flow, which works well. I didn't enjoy them enough to replay more than was required to advance the plot, but they were a great addition to spice things up a bit.  The regular price of To the Moon is a little higher than many other games, for the number of hours of enjoyment you'll get out of it, but even had I paid full price, rather than picking it up on sale, I would not have regretted the purchase. To the Moon is most definitely recommended for anyone who isn't turned off by extremely well-done pixel graphics and a cheesy, but completely enjoyable story.  To top it off I just noticed after I finished To the Moon tonight that there are two free DLCs available for free. What a great bonus to an already fantastic experience!  I was a bit disappointed with A Bird Story, Freebird's short 'game' released sometime after To the Moon, but having played To the Moon now I am very much looking forward to other productions from Freebird.
Beautiful game, gets you in the feels. 9 out of 10

In their simplicity, sprites can carry a hell of an emotional wallop. Back in the glory days of 16-bit RPGs, every game had its tearjerker. -- SPOILERS FOR 20 OR SO YEAR OLD GAMES TO FOLLOW -- Think of Celes' attempted suicide in Final Fantasy VI or Lucca's mom's legs being crushed in Chrono Trigger. --SPOILERS END--  To the Moon repurposes that style into combat-free, gameplay-light interactive story about the compromises we make to our dreams to be with the ones we love. Taking a cue from Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (and a bit of We Can Remember It For You Wholesale, P.K. ♥♥♥♥'s short story that became Total Recall), the player takes control of a pair of specialists trained to alter memories of the dying so they can feel like they had no regrets in their final moments.  The story has a lot to say about memory, life, death, love, autism, social expectations, and the responsibilities of science. A lot to unpack in a short amount of time. Worth it if you don't mind crying like a baby.

If you loved the animated movie 'UP', you will love this.  In terms of mechanics, essentially a 4 hour interactive novel, very linear game play. No skill required.  Plot line is very well done, and touches on many philosophical concepts. One could argue they are not explored fully. I would counter and say the author hints at it, creates an emotional impact using the plot line, and imparts it with the player without being patronizing. Well done.  IMHO buying and playing this game is a no brainer. Very satisfied after the 4 hour investment.

Not much of a game, but easily the best interactive story. Played nonstop for the 3 full hours and was not disappointed. A must buy.

I'm not recommending it simply because I didn't enjoy it overall and won't be interested in further chapters. It was an interesting idea & the devs did some nice work - I just think it's lacking the gameplay and enjoyment factor. It might be worth a buck or two, but I certainly wouldn't pay the $10 asking price for it (I got it in a bundle with many other games)  Pros: * Pleasant story * Nice visuals * Nice music * Short game (<4 hours)  Cons: * Juvenile humour (more annoying than humorous) * Tedious gameplay (slow walking, mostly wandering around just to find the next orb/memory just so you can get on with the story) * The minigames are repetitive and suck * No plot choices  I really wish I could move faster than a snails pace (or not have to walk at all and just click things immediately) and that there was actually something to do that made any difference (story choices). As it was I just felt like I was in a walking-simulator, slowly going through the paces to unlock the fixed story.   It was hard to be emotionally involved with the story when I was just wishing it would end already - I was glad when it finally did!
Simply outstanding,memorable,heartwarming,sweet,adventurous.  Best 4 hours of playing that I will cherish forever.

This is a simply beautiful game that everyone should experience. In order to fully experience the game, make sure to go in with no expectations. I went into this game expecting a very sad story, but I ended up felling pretty neutral. It was only when I let go of my expectations that I experienced the game in its fullest. Overall, this is an amazing game that shows the importance of the story telling in gameplay.  (Might I also add that the soundtrack is amazing.)
Oh, this game is defenitly should win the 'There is something in my eye award'.
A well written story with beautifully made art and music to boot. Definitely worth more than the ten dollars spent on it.

I love the storyline. It kept me wanting to play more and more. So heart breaking but I loved it. I love the chemist between the two workers as well. The humour was light which is a good thing. If you love visual novels, play this game. It is a remarkable indie.
this is a really good game, very interesting and has an amazing storyline
Help, I am emotionally compromised.
this is a really good game, very interesting and has an amazing storyline

Such feels. I was turned away by the art style when I first saw it in the store. But that was a mistake. After buying it in the Humble Bundle, I realize the style is perfect. Going backwards through an old dying man's memories is both uplifting and depressing. This is what people mean when they say video games are an art form. Maybe a movie or book could tell the same story, but it wouldn't draw anyone in like this does.

Bar none the best and most emotionally impactful story I have ever experienced in any medium. A short (around 3 hours) and simple ride, but what a rollercoaster of emotions it is, I fully recommend it to anyone but the most cold-hearted Grinch-like of individuals.
A short and cute game. Alot of both shocking, funny and sad momemts throughout the game. You will complete this game in about 4-5 hours. Should get some intel about the game before buying.

It's a short game, which means that for anyone busy that can't play games often it's pretty good, but if you want something that will last you longer than one day this may not be the game for you. Even though the game is simple, it's enjoyable, but the controls may be a little bit strange at times.  I think of it more as an interactive story rather than a game. The premise of the story is nice, although at one point my expectations were higher than what it delivered. I recommend this game for those of you who want to try out something different than traditional videogames, and also to those who like the story more than anything else.  I've been told that this game is 'sad' but personally, I don't think it's as emotional as The Walking Dead. There are some sad parts though. It's also very comical and pokes fun at many cartoon and comic references.

A fantastic, cinematic adventure that grips you from the very beginning and doesn't let go until the final, poignant moment. If you want a game then perhaps this game is not for you. Whilst it sports some semblance to a game with some moments, this is an interactive story.   A great game with great characterization, great story and a fantastic soundtrack. It will take roughly 3-4 hours to complete, but once you've finished you'll be itching for Freebird Games' sequel. Well worth a play, particularly if you're interested in a great story.
Call it a visual novel or whatever, but this game has a story that you won't forget and it is simply amazing how emotional can a pixel-graphic game be.
Simply beautiful...
To the   Moon   FEELS
One of the best story driven games out there, in my opinion. A really great experience .
'Why you?'  'Because one day… … I’m going to befriend one of them.'
Short, simple, nice story, cute.
Wow...just wow. Amazing game. And soundtrack is amazing too. The only downside was graphics, it coud've been something like bastion. But anyway get this game without thinking :)

Such a sad yet beautiful game. The music is original and very well done. Much of it is piano themed. The ending in particular really hits you hard. If it weren't for the layer of humor with the squabbling between Watts and Rosalene it'd be quite a dark experience. Much of the game is about exploring loss and bad choices made and passed. Note that this is an rpgmaker game. Despite what that might make those familiar with rpgmaker think it's really well done. I did a recorded playthrough as part of a project I'm doing which can be found  here .

This game hit home. Hard. Let's start with the fact I have a similar condition as one of the characters in the story. Their depiction was no less awkward than how I perceive the world around me every single day. The game ruined me. I was crying before I knew what hit me. This is a good thing. Then the rest of the story. Every time I knew it was coming and every time it happened it felt like it was coming out of a blind corner. My emotions were played like the piano played for most of the musical score. WHY DID THIS GAME MAKE ME CRY SO MUCH???? I had to play it all in one go. I could not tear myself away from it. I TRIED, but every time I made a new save, something in me said 'Just a little further. They can't be doing what you think they are..' and then I was proven wrong and my emotions got the better of me again.  There are a few minor problems with the game mechanics, but nothing that a quick reset of the brain and new view on a changing situation can't fix. And if nigh-on 20 years of gaming has taught me anything, it's to have a decent skill in adaptability.  I fully recommend this game. I can't recommend it hard enough. Go play it. Why are you still reading this? GO BUY THIS GAME!
TEARS EVERYWHERE WHAT IS THIS I AM NOT READING A KEY VN.

They should change this game name to 'To Feeladelphia'. All aboard the feels train!  But hey seriously, it's a good game with touching story and awesome music. It's like forrest gump movie but instead of seeing the journey of a kid to his adulthood, you're going to see a story about a dying man to his childhood.
This game was beautiful in so many ways

To the Moon is a short and sweet title that will take you on an emotonal rollercoaster. I would greatly recommend this game as it is beyond worth your money. To the Moon will take you throughout a man's life and will have you explore his memories so that you may help him accomplish his last wish -- To go to the Moon. Along the way your emotions will be flowing out of you like a   River  . One moment you will be laughing because of the game's clever writing, and the next you'll feel a deep connection with the characters. To the Moon plays off of older style graphics to bring you beyond amazing writing and connection to the characters. The gameplay is somewhat repetitive as it mostly consists of moving your character throughout a space and exploring an area from John's memories, but the writing and subtle music absolutely makes up this. For each time you have to explore an area, the writing makes up for it ten fold. The game itself is only about two to three hours long and is fairly simple to complete. The game also includes free mini story DLC about the two main characters and their life outside of the adventure in the main game. Overall, this game is WELL worth the money and I strongly recommend playing it.
Beautiful master piece.  pro tip: have tissue ready

A game either has to be really good or really bad for me to rate it, this game was very touching... I rate it in my top 5 games. Very unique and love how you learn the story backwards instead of forwards it makes it a mystery all the way through the game :)
Oh boy, what a game, fantastic story, characters, art, soundtrack. You must play this games, it's unlike anything i''ve seen. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is the only one that's close to it.

I have to say that this game is not what I expected. I expected a game where the player travels back in the old man's memories, and gives him a chance to relive his life - thus allowing the player to play through the man's life and make changes in it. That is not the case at all.  To the Moon IS NOT A GAME! It would be more accurately described as an interactive story. No, not a choose your own ending kind of story. The story is very linear, follows a laid out path and conclusion. The player is not often offered a choice, and even when he is, it doesn't matter. You can only follow one path, and that is that. As such, not only is To the Moon a story rather than a game, it posesses no replay value.  So, is it worth buying? Yes, definitely. Even though the graphics look like it came from the mid-1990s, the story is compelling, and the music beautiful. It's a tear-jerker, and I often felt myself wanting to go through 'just one more scene'.  To the Moon has no keybinding controls, and even though that is a big bugbear of mine, its controls are bound to the number pad, not WASD. As a left-handed person, well done development team.   Also, there is no volume control for the music. Sole control over volume comes from your own speakers or headset.  In short, To the Moon is not a game, has no replay value, no control bindings, and no volume control. But its compelling story and beautiful music more than compensate. Definitely worth the price of admission.

3 hour game. Cried for last hour of game. 11/10 Better than titanic.  This game puts comic relief before the sad stuff. So I sat here and quickly went from laughing to quivering with shame at my tears.  A very philosophical game that will always leave you wanting to know more, even at the very end. Narrative is just so amazing. Soundtrack is pretty good too.  Otherwise its way too short to justify a 12 dollar price tag (Get it in a humble bundle or something), along with zero replay value.    If you have this game, finish it once. Its worth it.

I didn't know what to expect when buying this game, but somehow this gem managed to work its way into my heart. I'm generally a stoic person, but I was openly crying by the end of this game. It is by far the most touching story I have ever heard or played.

Time spent playing so far: 1.7 hours duration of ownership: 1 day First thoughts: Story rich and mysterious Number of times cried: once (when she refuses treatment) Extra thoughts: This game is secretly about the problems of lack of universal healthcare I will update this as I play more I bought it when it was 75% off and it looks like its already worth it. I would recomend this to most people (the exception being people who exclusivly love fps games).
Very awesome game. It's a very sad and melancholic atmosphere, you can really feel with all the characters!
meh. dude has an unhappy life. make him think he actually had a happy one. too escapist. really dragged on in the end.
A straight playthrough of this game is a mere 3 hours, but they will be a greatly invested 3 hours. This game is heartwrenching and you will never forget it.
There isn''t much gameplay in the game but the amazing story it tells makes more then up for the lack of gameplay. If you want to experience a novel in the form of a game this is the one to play.

With this kind of game you really have to take a gamble based on reviews and in this case, the reviews really let me down. I'd really like my 4 hours back.  The controls are terrible but that's kind of to be expected for an independent release like this. Still, there are levels where movement is painfully slow, it's easy to get caught on odd items in the background, and it takes more effort to do what you want to do than it should.  All of this could be forgiven, however, if the story made up for it. It did not. I had to wait an hour for the hook, then got dragged along a poorly paced and poorly told story that concluded with an ending which was unneccessarily empty and disappointing.  There are several great examples of indie games that focus on story, but this is not one of them. Save yourself a lot of wasted time and play something else.
Didn't cry cause I was a big boi. 11/10

There's a huge circlejerk around this game, so don't take serious big amount of downvotes negative reviews have.   The game is praised for its music and story, and while music is really good and touching, there's nothing particulary good about the story, outside of how it ends. It's a bit dull and dragged out, with a surprisingly big number of unfunny jokes and edgy dialogs between two main characters. So even though the ending will make you cry, unless you're toughskinned, there's too much tosh before that. I didn't feel like it was all worth it.  I don't want to offend those who liked this game, because I understand that someone was touched by it right from the start, it's just I'm not one of those people. And I consider myself sensitive.

Pros: Interesting story  Cons: Terrible gameplay, just clicking all over the place Boring, very linear Slow Absolutely the worst dialogue I've had to suffer through, destroys the game  Other thoughts: I feel as though this could have been someone's project for a game design class using RPG Maker. I will give the author credit, they completed a game, however I cannot recommend this game to players. There are key aspects of this game which are designed or implemented poorly and detract from the overall gaming experience and enjoyment.
Didn't do much for me, I could not get imersed in the storyline, this does not mean that you won't... but i didn't. Picked this up cheap so cannot complain too much.

If you like and enjoy very emotional stories than this might be a game for you. If you hate RPGMaker games or reading in general better pass on this one. The plot is intersting and the ending is quite nice and emotional. You can even discuss the story with other people.  And I get that it's a game, since it can be presented differently than in completly written form,  BUT the gameplay is sometimes really slow and not really woven into the story really well.   And since I am no big fan of tedious running around I can't recommend it to everyone. It has its fanbase but it's not worth 8€.

The story itself is largely a ripoff of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, except that film was so brilliantly written and delivered that it's completely unfair to compare them. Go and see that film if you haven't, it's genius.  To The Moon's writing is just painful, as it tries desperately hard but fails to be funny around what is ultimately supposed to be emotional and touching material, but the emotional aspects themselves just come across as trying too hard and are not really that engaging, to be honest I found myself literally wincing inside. It's also  so slow  getting through dialogue, if this was simply written as a book I could've read through the conversations about five times as quickly, but the game just makes you wait for each and every painful and not particularly well-written line.   Finally there is actually no game here, each scene is just go and find the same five or so objects that are identical to the objects you found in the previous scene, none of them are even hidden in any interesting ways or require any puzzle solving ability.  Definitely not my cuppa tea.

To the Moon is an interactive novel that uses brilliant and unique ideas into storytelling and this game's story is one I don't see myself forgetting for quite a while. The only problem with this game is the aspects that make it a game since there is none. As previously stated it is an interactive novel and it is PURELY an interactive novel and features no gameplay whatsoever.
