To the Moon: An “Atmospheric Adventure” that sets the Standard of Storytelling

I'm going to be the contrarian here and write what I didn't liked about the game's story. If you want to read another review saying 'To The Feelz' then feel free to move ahead.  That being said, before I explain which are my points of disappointment, I want to say that this is indeed an amazing game. It is short, standing at 5 hours of gameplay for most cases, so if you're looking for a lenghty visual novel, that's not the case here. However, it is a very good short story worth playing. It is mostly story though, beyond some minor puzzles and exploration. Also, it has a profound soundtrack. Overall, I would give this game 4 out of 5 stars.  Why not 5 stars? Keep reading, but I suggest you finish the game first.  *SPOILER ALERT*  Since you're exploring Johnny's memories, the story is told from his point of view. We see him dealing with River's illness and staying by her side until the end. We even see him granting her last wish, by allowing her to die to save their dream home. You know that this is going to be a sad story, since this is the story of a couple of scientists granting an old man's dying wish. However, I can't understand how the characters almost completely overlook the saddest point of all, which was River's ordeal.  Let me explain... while you play the game moving from the present to the past, you see that as part of River's illness she develops an obsession with creating rabbit origami. Every time she creates one of these she asks Johnny to describe what it is, but Johnny is unable to provide a satisfactory answer for her. At some point on the story, it is revealed that she started this obsession after Johnny told her something about their first meeting. You don't know for certain what he told her, but you know that his friend Nick knows about it. Since Johnny met Nick in middle school, you know that the event is something that happened at that time.  Now, when you learn the actual mystery of the game, you get to know that Johnny doesn't remember most of his childhood after the trauma of losing his brother and taking some medicine to forget about it. But here's the true tragedy: Johnny also forgot his actual first meeting with River when they were kids. It was the time when their connection started, the one that would last for all their lives. They were stargazing, they saw a bunny on the stars with the moon as its belly and Johnny ended up giving away the platypus stuffed toy as a present to River. It is the same platypus that she would keep for all her life. She also tells him about her love for lighthouses and how she would like to befriend one, one day.  So now, let's look at the story from River's point of view. She met Johnny when she was a little girl and they had a strong connection. He promises to meet her at the same spot next year, but that doesn't happens. She remembers about him, because she keeps her gifts. Later, by chance, she actually meets him again and they go out and eventually get married. And after they live almost a lifetime together, Johnny confesses something that makes her aware that he doesn't remember their first meeting and what may be the most crucial point of their relationship. But, River having a mental illness and being introverted, she doesn't just tells him: 'What the hell, Johnny?! Don't you remember that time when we were kids?' No… instead she tries to show him. She makes paper bunnies and asks him to 'see', to make him remember the moon. The last bunny even has different colors, because the moon is its belly. As final challenge, she asks him to throw away a bag Johnny has given her when they first met, and he does because for him it doesn't means anything. So in the end, she dies knowing that the man she married is not the same boy she met on the cliff that night when they were friends.  That's the true sad story here. River's story. And what I cannot understand is how the main characters of our story, the scientists, are completely ignorant about it. They saw it, they must understand what was happening, but they don't even make a reference about River's point of view. I know she's already dead, but not recognizing how hard it must have been for her it's the same as ignoring it. For me, it's like saying: 'Yes, too bad for her, but this is Johnny's story, not hers'.  In the end, I agree with Dr. Watts, Johnny didn't actually wanted to go To The Moon, what he wanted was to remember why he felt that the moon was special. He wanted to remember the moment that he actually met River. I think that would have been fairer to both sides of the story: Johnny's and River's.

I personally am not one for 16 bit games but this was simply beautiful. The artwork is amazing, visuals are stunning and the music really helps set the mood weither it's happy, sad, or menacing.  The minisodes are equally as amazing, providing outside information about our dear technicians, Neil and Eva. The minisodes provide us with a different perspective with a dark looming cliffhanger, soon to be answered in the future. This is a beautifully tragic series and I cannot wait for the sequel, Finding Paradise, where we will pick up with our beloved technicians and reunite with a character from the past. This game is brilliant - actually a piece of art.  Controls are sometimes a bit clunky (limited by the engine used), and the graphics, though cute, are nothing to write home about (again, engine), but damn, the author has a story to tell, and that story is worth telling. It would make a great sci-fi novel or even a movie. It is elaborate, somewhat linear, but (especially the ending) very open for interpretation, there are a lot of smart clues, and the free minisodes further spice it up. The story is told with care, creativity, humor, and great dialogs. It unfolds at the right pace and involves you to the right extent. It's not predictable. It makes you think and feel. And it is complemented by a beautiful, beautiful soundtrack.  Seriously, if you have a soft spot for clever, story rich adventures, and/or great sci-fi, just get it.

For those that haven't played this yet, I'll be as spolier free as possible.  ---  To the Moon has a beautiful story and a wonderful soundtrack, just don't buy it if you're one to skip dialogue/cutscenes to simply get into gameplay, because the story is all there really is in this game and is the only real motivation to play it. What you do is explore the setting around you by clicking the left mouse button to move your character, and click on things in the environment to get more story, whether that be to talk to a character, or to read something. A lot of the time, doing that, you'll collect colored energy orbs; eventually you'll collect enough orbs (five at most) to then go to a significant object, and shoot the orbs at it to get into the next section of the story and new setting, to do it again. Before you do though, you must unlock the object by breaking its shield with the orbs, then you'll have to do a very easy puzzle where you flip over parts of an image to make the picture whole. There are a few moments that are unique to the rest of it (most that work well, and one that is just okay), like a small part early on that plays on your expectations of the game due to its overhead 16-bit visuals.  In general though, the game is well worth the money it's priced at as its story will make you smile, laugh, and perhaps for some, even cry, though if not, at least feel heavily for what is going on. The story is accompanied, and I would say even enhanced by what is pretty much the only sound in the game, which is its soundtrack. Since there is no voice work, it helps that the dialogue is extremely well written, and what doesn't seem to be, is intentionally so to help you further understand the characters personalities. The 16-bit visuals do justice to the character models as well, as they're expressive just enough for you to understand and feel for these characters. As to not spoil much (since you'll want to experience it yourself), you control two characters through the journey of memories: Sigmund Corps' Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene; their job is to use a machine to get inside ones mind to create artificial memories for their patients, patients that are in their last few remaining days of life and want to go in peace.  Their patient is Johnny, an elderly man that you soon figure out has one last wish: to go to the moon, so Rosalene and Watts have to figure out how to get him there. It's not literal, as it's through his memories. When you start, you go from his eldest age, and at first gradually, to his younger self. That is what the story is about, learning about Johnny's life through the years, happy and sad. Since you're basically going backwards in time, this lends the story to have mystery, and it makes you ask questions, giving you motivation to want to push forward for those answers. There's a lot of sweet, charming moments in his story, but it's mostly filled with moments of hard times. It's largely up to the two Drs. that give the back and forth moments of laughter, as they don't seem to get along with one another. Watt's being the arrogant, seeming to not care as much character, and Rosalene being what seems to be the less clumsy, well mannered one. They may speak and be the playable characters to see this story through, but it's really about Johnny's story; they're just on the journey with you.  There are several other characters in it that are important as well which I'll leave you to discover on your own. There are also references to culture: from books, internet sites, TV shows, and other video games. The game takes four hours to complete give or take (it took me four and a half almost exactly). You may think that that's too short, but it's actually just right. I fully recommend this to anyone that just wants a great story in a game, but if you're someone that wants fantastic gameplay, this may not be for you. If you are however the one to take interest in it, then once you're finished, it's a game that'll stick with you. While it lacks replay value after the credits role, you'll be wishing to see a friend or family member play it just to see their reaction and to discuss it.

While it wasn't totally engaging all the way through, and the dialogue was borderline woeful in the beginning, I felt that it finished strongly enough to be worth the 4.5 hours it took me to leisurely read through.  I'd recommend it at any price below €5, nothing more. There is only one achievement (beating it) and there are no alternate endings or worthwhile choice branches. I only have good things to say about this game.  On a whole, To the Moon is a linear adventure/puzzle game. You explore locations in order, occasionally breaking to engage in puzzles that allow you to move on. The puzzles aren't hard, but they aren't so easy that they're boring, either. There's really not much else to say about gameplay. You walk around, trigger cutscenes or puzzles, wash, rinse, repeat.  Where To the Moon really shines, though, is in the story it tells. And oh my God, is the story good. The game focuses on storytelling, to the point where it's almost self-aware. It's such a bittersweet tale that the player experiences. I honestly broke down and cried during some parts because it's told so well and you really form an emotional attachment to the characters. The music is pleasant, as well. It really plays up the emotion factor of the game and helps to convey feelings at certain points.
This is the only game that has actually made me cry, 100% the best story in any game I've played to date. I cannot stress enough that you need to play this game.

I highly recommend this game, especially if you are the type of person who appreciates good story.

I got hit in the feels and cried like a baby, even more crying than Life Is Strange.  This is a dialog-heavy story-driven game, the gameplay isn't very challenging, it's a little more involved than an interactive novel but definitely leans casual. Beautiful score that really is the make-and-break difference for this game having full emotional impact. This game has a lot of heart. The themes are pretty heavy, there are some seriously depressing moments but there also is enough humor to somewhat balance it out so it doesn't feel dark.  As an aspiring game developer myself, I'm very inspired by what works about the game but somewhat meh about the things that don't work well for me. I'm not a fan of having to force my monitor to go into low resolution mode to play full screen. I'd have much prefered to play the game with my Xbox controller than with the keyboard and mouse; it uses the arrow keys for navigation instead of WASD so I can only assume that the developer is left-handed, but there's no way to remap the controls.   The graphics are acceptable, but for my retro asthetic I prefer the pixel art of Stardew Valley. The outdoor map design felt a bit haphazard and unnatural. The higher resolution cartoon cutscenes worked well.  Overall, I'm pretty happy with the game and give it a 9/10. I love sci-fi and psychology and really enjoy the various themes and tropes of this game. Great music more than makes up for the mixed-quality visual asthetic. Although the game is pretty short, clocking in at about 5 hours, it's such a memorable experience that it's well worth paying full price.

Once you get past the subpar visual design (which is an engine limitation, easily forgivable), there's a really heartfelt story to be enjoyed here and still has one of my favorite endings in a game. 8/10

For $10 I didn't know so much story can happpen in a single play span. If I was going to redo any game or show, no doubt would I do this again <3

On first impressions, this game looks like a pretty poor, low resolution, wanabe game. The graphics are crude, the UI is not good, and there are some really silly elements within the game. A few minutes in, I found myself wondering if this was something I was going to go through with, or just give up and uninstall...  Quite quickly, though, the story grabs you, and although you still think the graphics are bad, that slowly becomes less important. And then the story really kicks in; at some points intriguing, at others sinister, it turns into a deeply emotional tale of a dying man's life, and where it all went so wrong. Back in time we go looking for answers.  The final revelations are just so mind blowing. I didn't actually cry, but, for me, it was such a deep emotional experience that changed me, and left a lasting impression - one which I still remember over a year later. It's the type of experience you really want to share with someone (probably because you want to talk about it).  It's a definite recommendation from me, but, be aware, you are playing this for the story, not for the graphics or gameplay.

It's amazing how great a simple game made with RPG Maker XP can be. This game had me laughing and crying, and no game has done that in a long time. The story is incredible and very touching. If you are looking for a game this is not it. The gameplay mostly consists of moving to the next place to advance the story. There is very rarely anything complicated about getting your next task done. To the Moon is barely a game but that does not mean it is not worth playing, everything it lacks in gameplay it makes up for in story. The story is heartfelt and touching with a few funny moments brough in by our heroes Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts as they travel though Johnny Wyles memories to find the perfect moment to implant a false desire that will create a chain reaction of false memories to create the false memory that will fulfil his dying wish to go To the Moon. To accompany the touching story is a beautiful sound track that fits perfectly with the story.    9/10

Out of all the games i've seen and played so far in my 25 years of life, this is the one that got to me the most. This game (just by a thread) is just simply amazing and just adds more to what gaming is all about. With this, story is king above all else. When I finished this game, my heart 'broke in two,' and that's saying something coming from a person like me. There's very few stories that goes into this direction, but this one really touched my heart with something I can finally relate to.  The only regret that I have about this game is the price tag at the time of purchased: I've paid too little. I got it on a sale and after finishing the game, I wanted to pay full price to support the developer for he has great abilities to share.  If you get anything out of this review it is this: 11/10, pay full price (my opinion), and make sure you share this with the world.  PS: if the Auther of this game reads my review, then all I want to say is thanks for what you have did, done, and will do.

I bought the five anniversary package on steam before Christmas, and it was my first game in this platform. You can identify how important it is to me.  Kan Gao and freebird Games, thank you for your game design and story. I played it exactly on 25 Dec 2016 for the whole Christmas day, and read the English dialogue carefully word by word, and make notes on them, including the whole words between John and River when they met and chatted under the moon. Because of the careful reading and making notes, it actually took me more than 13 hours to go over the whole game, until 6 am on 26 Dec.  I am totally moved by this game, even though I heard of this game for years and knew it is affecting (That is why it is my first steam game). But still, when I really went through the game, I felt I recalled a number of forgotten things in my own life, just like John's oblivion.   This plot is about love, amnesia, autism, and telling to each other. The theme of love includes many dimensions: the obscure love between John and River when they was a kid, the love between them after the marriage but John has forgotten the past, the eternal love between them engraved by the lighthouse and even built real graves under it, the metaphor of lighthouse about communication and love, the expression of love and reminder by River of origami rabbits....   I suppose, besides love, the meaning of life and the importance of forgotten things are the most important elements.I just started the game without any background knowledge of the game, expect for the game's goodness. As the plot went on, it was just like a touching movie to me. There are no fight, no level and no 'death' in this game, instead, it has humorous dialogue between two doctors, impressive life development of John, and more importantly, the consideration of meaning of life. The game is also a detective plot, letting player to find out the final answer 'why he want to go to the moon' by flash-back of John's whole life. As I describe, when I read the dialogues in reversed scenes, it recalled me my own life experience, just like what we did in the exploration of John's life. By doing so, some forgotten pieces of my life have also been collected, smooth and peaceful.   In addition, the BGM is so impressive, a number of praises are already for it. So I did not comment on more here.  Thank you for your game again, I am going to play the spin-off small games, and the 'a bird story'. But especially, I am looking forward to your new game, which is another case of two doctors, 'finding paradise'.
